more important the ideas behind it on one side of this war were the cyer punks
these were people who wanted to see this information spread wildly they wanted to

Stinger missiles and you could be tried and prosecuted as such at the same time the government
realized that uh these ideas were perhaps potentially interesting to some people and that they would want them and

embodied by the Clipper chip and the idea was this is a totally
opaque chip uh that no one knows the internals no one knows about the details
of the internals and that the government would embed this into every piece of consumer Communications equipment every

the E droppers during this time is that cryptography is not a banana that is to say that information

one person in the world with a banana if that friend then gives the banana to someone else there is still only one

worse by one of the main cyppher Punk mantras Cypher Punk's right code a lot of great work had been done

of your normal uh requests and uh for everything that isn't uh Google bound
just goes straight to the internet uh it's totally unmolested there's no performance implications you get your
full uh internet connectivity speed if it sees something that's uh for a Google service which doesn't require a login

Google mail or Google Checkout then it will siphon that traffic off strip the
your Google cookie from the request and forward it on to the Google sharing proxy the Google sharing proxy maintains
a pool of identities where uh each identity is a cookie that's been issued
by Google as well as some unique uh user agent headers or not just user agent but HTTP headers uh these are the things
that are sort of like the fingerprint of a web browser right your user agent header what content encodings your web browser sends that kind of thing each
identity has sort of a unique fingerprint and when a request comes into the Google sharing proxy uh the
HTTP headers from the client are stripped off and the headers from this identity are put on and then that

response to the client and uh then we try and sort of like take step it up a
notch by encrypting this link from the client to the Google sharing proxy so you get SSL protection on your local
area network for uh Google services that ordinarily don't even provide https

that um if you look at how pgp Works probably you know almost seems like
almost nobody uses pgp but most people know how it works right which is um let's say that I want to send an email
to Bob I get Bob's public key and I encrypt my email with Bob's public key
and then I send it to Bob if I want to send another email to Bob I use Bob's
same public key encrypt that email send it to Bob on and on and on and the
problem is that if any point Bob's public key is compromised then every
email that you've ever sent using that key is now also compromised that if I
send an email to Bob today it is secure but if even 20 years in the future
someone manages to compromise Bob's public key that email is now lost so the big problem is that one key
compromise affects all previous
correspondents the second problem is that you're in this weird situation where the secrecy of what I write is
dependent on your security practices which is kind of the opposite of what I want you know I'm pretty paranoid I have

security practices to protect the secrecy of the things that I'm writing and the third problem is that you have

nice right because Bob received this message and he knows that it came from me but I would like for Bob to know that it came from me but also to be able to
at some point say that wasn't really me uh but the problem is that it's undeniable it as it is and so uh what
these uh cryptographers were proposing in their paper uh was something called off the Record messaging and the way
that this works is that everyone continues to have their public private key pair as you know we're familiar with
but the difference is that those those key pairs are never used to encrypt actual data instead they're only used to
sign an ephemeral key exchange that you do uh between both parties so Alice and Bob
exchange ephemeral Keys which they sign using their key pair so that you know
that you have authenticity you're really talking to the right person then you use that ephemeral key pair to actually
exchange messages and what you do is that every time you exchange a message you also
include um half of a key exchange one part of a key exchange so appended
prepended or embedded in your message is also a key exchange which means that every time you exchange messages um you
get a new uh key exchange which means that the key that you're using to
exchange messages can continue rolling forward and uh so not only are you using
ephemeral keys but also every time you exchange a message you have a new key that is constantly rolling forward so
there's not any one key that can ever be compromised to affect all of your previous messages because that key is constantly changing and it's never
stored anywhere permanently furthermore so you have a message it's encrypted with this session
key and instead of using digital signatures to authenticate that message you use a message authentication code
and the me message authentication code is keyed off of the session key it's a derivative of the session key so the
sign signatures are undeniable because they only have one possible author but
uh Macs have two possible authors right because two possible people know the key
that is used to construct the Mac both Alice and Bob so if Bob receives a

uh message authentication key is a derivative of the session key and the session key is constantly rolling
forward it means that the Mac keys are constantly rolling forward as well and once you've rolled forward to a new Mac
key uh it is no longer sensitive the old one uh is can be given away it doesn't
matter if you keep it secret or not and so they explicitly publish it uh openly

actually a zrt key stream and uh zrt key is a pretty nice protocol that was
designed by Philip Zimmerman and it was done with uh forward Security in mind the way it works is that um you
negotiate a ephemeral session key between the two phones and then from that ephemeral session key you derive uh
what's known as a short authentication string and that short authentication string is
then displayed when the call is connected so there's this you know problem of key distribution and
authenticity right you know that whenever you want to send someone uh a pgp encrypted email you have to find
their public key and then once you have it you don't know if it's really there you have to maybe check the signatures or call them on the phone and be like
